architectures it's hard to debug them
and understand what's going on and

there's a couple answers to this

runtimes so now understanding what
observability is what's open telemetry
open telemetry is simply just an open-
source framework for for observability
you're going to hear me shortening this
to hotel throughout the presentation if
you haven't heard that before um and
some of the main things it's doing is
it's standardizing the observability
community and preventing vendor lock in
and in fact it's actually the second
most popular and committed to cncf
project just behind kubernetes which is
quite a
feat so there's there's kind of two big
things that open telemetry is helping us
do the first one is it's helping you to
instrument your code to produce
telemetry data uh another term they use
for this is signals and there's three
different types of signals or telemetry
you can produce the first is just bog
standard logs that we're all used to um
you know we're we've all done this we've
all seen this the main thing to note
here is typically in open telemetry
you'll be using whatever is standard in
your programming language and then
you'll use a bridging layer to send that
logs over to the open telemetry system
second thing we're all probably familiar
with is metrics just measuring values
over time there's counters gauges
histograms things like that um and this
is answering questions like what's the
request count my app is receiving or cpu
usage over time the third is traces and
so a trace just consists of a bunch of
different spans where each span has a
start time and an end time and a name
and a bunch of metadata associated with
it and that spans measuring a unit of
work so perhaps a call from a client or
a api responding to that call where they
get useful though is we combine all
these spans together in a trace by
linking them in parent child
relationships and by doing this we can
we can understand the relationship of
how things are flowing through our code
and we can understand timing
relationships of how long things take so
that's all pretty handy but it gets even
handier when you talk about distributed
tracing which is just what if i could
understand the flow of requests through
my entire microser architecture so on
the left here we have a graph of a
couple services in our architecture
we've got service a which is calling
services b and e and then b is calling
services c and d and we can see on the
right the spans that all these uh
services are producing are tied into a
distributed trace so you'll note that
under a it's calling b and then later
it's calling e and under b it's got the
spans for c and d now importantly when
we're sending requests through a system
like this we need a way to distribute
the context of this trace through the
system right because each span is
emitted from different servers so we
need a way to tie them together and so
typically if for example you have http
requests going between services you
would like stick a trace context header
in the http request and then it would be
able to tie that all
together okay so going forward we're
going to be focusing on tracing uh and
just quickly the second thing helps us
with is to collect process and forward

hotel collector which helps us do that
it allows you to take in telemetry data

you're running your infrastructure maybe

jagger or
prometheus this is the main thing that

interg instrumentation work so again
interg guest telemetry is tracing this
interaction between guest modules and
the way that this works is dependent on
the runtime and dependent on how you do
component
composition so if you're doing dynamic
composition maybe your runtime allows
you to communicate to another guest
running on a web assembly runtime across
the network somewhere or maybe it allows
you to communicate in different runtimes
um on the same machine but but different
hosts uh if you're doing that kind of
dynamic composition fundamentally you're
just making a host call between these
two components and so in this case
interest telemetry is actually kind of
trivial because we're just doing more
things in the host and so we can just
trivially emit some telemetry at that
point where it gets a little trickier uh
and and more interesting is in
statically composed components so for
example in spin uh we we support
statically composed components and when
you hand that off to the runtime it just
sees this single component and there's
not as clear of a path for the host to
emit uh something at that boundary
between those two components thankfully
there is things we can do for example we
could work in the future to add support
in wm time because it is aware about
that boundary to to add some
instrumentation hooks into that point um
but no no such work has been done to do
that yet so a lot of room for
improvement there the the other option
we have to to explore is we could do
composition where we add an adapter
module so imagine we have this do
something interface we could put an
adapter uh component in between that
virtualizes that interface just
transparently passing through to the
backing component but by virtualizing it
it also would emit some telemetry data
that could trace that interaction
so let's run back auto instrumentation
kind of figure out the pros and cons
here the big obvious one is that there's
no effort required from the developer
you just very conveniently get this
telemetry out of the box which is handy
it's cross language obviously because we
basically get that out of web assembly
with web assembly being polyglot you
don't need to worry about that you just
hand it your components and you'll get
your tracing and also there's a really
bright future i think with what we can
do with the intergust telemetry stuff so
lots of room to grow there the main
obvious problem with this auto
instrumentation is it's not customizable
you can't emit spans according to your
own business logic or things that matter
to you you're just kind of stuck with
what you get from auto
instrumentation so that obviously leads
us to the third place we can emit
telemetry which is intra guest telemetry
um so let's dive into that and before we

instrumentation uh specifically how you
do instrumentation with open telemetry
so let's do that imagine you have a
program just some rust or go program and
you want to trace it you're using the
open telemetry sdks so you're going to
start with a tracer provider and that
tracer provider is going to allow you to
create a tracer now you can of course
create multiple tracers it allows that
and you'll typically do that if you want
to have like a different tracer for
different scopes of the codebase um but
in practice most of the time you'll just
have a single tracer that you're
using with the tracer whenever you want
to start tracing a individual unit of
work a span you'll create a span and
typically you'll want to uh take some
sort of external trace context and use
that to parent the span so imagine
you've got like your incoming handler
and it's handling a request coming in
that request might have some context
from your distributed services that you
want to reparent that span under so
we've got this external trace context
and to tie that into this span we're
going to use something called a
propagator and that propagator can
support a variety of different formats
but typically it looks like a text map
propagator which is basically pulling
the standard trace context format out of
your http request headers and then
parsing that out so with that uh context
in hand we're going to hand that off to
the span create it with the proper
parent child relationships and then when
the span's first created that's going to
trigger onstart for your span processors
now in a open telemetry instrumentation
stack like this you could have one
processor you could have multiple
processors and the processors are doing
things like batching um your your spans
that's kind of the typical use case or
they might be doing things like mutating
the spans slightly for certain use cases
or or printing them out things like that
in practice most of the time you
basically just have a batching span
processor here uh on starts called with
the span you do your thing in your code
eventually that span's going to end
you're going to call on end on it which
will also trigger the span processor and
then that's going to go ahead and say
"okay you're done with this span i'm
going to let the span exporter know that
it's good to export this span now
because we've finished it and it has all
the metadata we need to send off so
we've got our span exporter here and
then that's responsible for actually
getting this metadata out of the process
to the open telemetry collector that you
have running maybe as a sidecar or a
damon near your
program so that's the flow of tracing
instrumentation with open telemetry uh

the the host executing that component
and then we have the guest itself

trace get request execute the component
the guest emits a span and then during

that key value as an example it's

be properly parented like that but
you're not able to do that unfortunately
you can't tie those in those those would
show up as a as a different span and the

guest
